New Records: RJ Barrett finished his first career triple-double, scoring 25 points, grabbing 10 rebounds, and collecting a career-high 15 assists. This was the first time a Raptor had collected those stats in the same game and the first time a Canadian had ever had 25 points, 10 rebounds, and 15 assists.
Jakob Poeltl followed up a career-high 19-rebound performance against Detroit with a career-high 35-point performance in Boston.
Key Match Events: Jayson Tatum nailed a game-winning, buzzer-beating three-pointer to give the Boston Celtics a 126-123 victory over the visiting Raptors.
Tatum fell one assist shy of a triple-double, compiling 24 points, 11 rebounds, and 9 assists.
Jaylen Brown led all Celtics with 27 points while chipping in with 6 rebounds and 7 assists.
The Celtics attempted 61 three-pointers and made 21, while Toronto attempted 23 three-pointers.
The Celtics outscored the Raptors 63-27 on three-pointers, while Toronto outscored Boston 76-42 in points in the paint.
Toronto had a chance to steal a win in Boston with the game tied at 114, but Tatum missed a potential game-winning buzzer-beater, leading to overtime.
Jaylen Brown hit his second triple of overtime, giving the Celtics a 2-point lead.
RJ Barrett had a chance to win the game but his layup attempt was blocked by Neemias Queta.
Tatum improvised and took a stepback three to win the game in overtime.
Pre-Game Insights: Boston entered the game well-rested, having not played since shellacking the Brooklyn Nets on Wednesday.
Toronto was playing less than 24 hours after losing a tight game at home to Detroit.
Post-Match Reflections: After the game, Tatum was asked about the game-winner and said, 'I got a lot of problems in life. Confidence has never been one of them.'

'I worked too hard at my craft. I’ve played too much basketball to ever doubt the next shot. Whether it’s an in-and-out miss or I miss the entire rim, I know what I’m capable of and you always believe the next one is going in.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Celtics were without Jrue Holiday, Kristaps Porzingis, and Jaden Springer, while the Raptors were without Scottie Barnes, Bruce Brown, Immanuel Quickley, Kelly Olynyk, and Ja’Kobe Walter.
The Raptors' two victories have come against Kyle Lowry’s Sixers and DeMar DeRozan’s Kings.
